MEMBERS OF THE BOARD CHARLES W. BRYAN Governor PRANK MARSH Secretary of State GEO. W. MARSH ;.... , State Auditor T. W. BASS.. l..State Treasurer WM. H. SMITH state Tax Commissioner TAX COMMISSIONERS OP NEBRASKA The position ol State Tax Commissioner was created by the Con - stitution of 1920. Prior thereto the work was performed by a secre - tary to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment, the Tax Com - missioner being made a member of the board. Those who have served as Commissioner under the constitutional provision. are: NAME COUNTY SERVED W. H. OSBORNE 0u5ter....... April 25, 1921 to April 18, 1923 WM. H. SMITH Seward: -April 18, 1923 to Jan. 12, 1925 T. E. WILLIAMS Hamilton Jan. 12, 1925 to Jan. 8, 1929 HARRY W. SCOTT....Lancaster Jan. 8, 1929 to Dec. 1, 1930 WM. H. SMITH Seward.. Jan. 8, 1931 to

. liETTKB OP TRANSMITTAIi December 15, 1931. Hon. Charles W. Bryan, Governor of Nebraska, Lincoln. My dear Governor: I am transmitting to you herewith the annual report of this de - partment for the year 1931. The report contains a tabulation of the abstracts of assessments made by the various county assessors of the state, as well as other tabulations compiled by this department during the past year. I want to thank you and the members of the State Board of Equalization and Assessment for your cooperation during the year and also the county assessors and county clerks throughout the state' as well as all others who have cooperated in any way. Years very truly, WM. H. SMITH, ■ State Tax Commissioner.

J 345,779.33 425,120 1924 403,641.81 411,411 1923 372,765.87 STATEMENT NO. 13 MAXIMUM TAX LEVIES Many inquiries come to the Tax Commissioner for information con - cerning the maximum tax levies that may be made. The following statement has therefore been compiled, containing the information referred to. Special levies such as paving, irrigation, bond, etc., are not included. The citations to the Compiled Statutes for 1929 were assembled by Hon. George W. Ayres, Assistant Attorney General. STATE ■ There is no constitutional limitation upon the amounts the Leg - islature may appropriate although there is some limitation upon the purposes for which the appropriations may be made. The State Board of Equalization and Assessment is authorized to levy sufficient tax to meet the appropriations made by the Legislature and in addition thereto a levy of not to exceed two-tenths of one mill on the dollar for the purpose of paying off registered warrants outstanding against the general fund of the state. (See Sec. 77-1007). COUNTIES The constitution limits the amount of tax that may. be levied by county authorities without authorization by a vote of the electors of the county to fifty cents per one hundred dollars actual valuation as determined by the assessment rolls. See Section 5 of Article VIII of the Constitution. The power of a county board to levy taxes is further limited by statute to thirty-five cents per hundred dollars oh the actual valuation as determined by the assessment rolls in counties having over thirty - five hundred population. In counties having a population of thirty - five hundred or less the county board may levy not to exceed fifty cents per hundred dollars valuation as determined by the assessment rolls. (See Sec. 77-1801). The levy for ordinary county revenue including the support of the poor is limited by statute to not more than three mills on the dollar valuation. (See Sec. 77-1801). • •

. STATE OF NEBRASKA TOWNSHIPS The aggregate maximum levy for township purposes is three mills on the dollar of the actual valuation. (See Sec. 26-269). CITIES AND VILLAGES The maximum amount which may be assessed and collected in a city of the first class having from 5,00 0 to 25,000 inhabitants to de - fray its general incidental and all other municipal expenses in addi - tion to special assessments and special taxes, is eighteen mills. (See Sec. 16-702). See Note. • Cities of the second class and villages can not levy taxes for gen - eral revenue purposes to exceed five mills. (See Sec. 17-129 and 77 - 1201). SCHOOLS The aggregate school tax levied for general school purposes in school districts organized under Articles 3 and 6 of the School Law (rural and village schools) shall not exceed eight mills oh the dollar of the actual valuation of the district unless a greater levy which can not, however; exceed twenty mills, has been, authorized by a vote of the electors of the district. In addition to the tax for general school purposes, a tax of not exceeding two mills per annum can be levied for building purposes If the levy of such a tax is voted by the electors of the district. (See Sec. 79-213 and 79-216.) In city school districts the levy for general school purposes can not exceed twenty mills per annum. (See Sec. 79-2523). ' In the school- district of Lincoln the aggregate amount of the school tax levied for all purposes In any one year can not exceed 15 mills which, however, may be Increased by popular vote to 17 mills, unless a greater levy for certain enumerated purposes is authorized by the electors. (See Sec. 79-2621 of C. S. Supp. 1931). In the school district of the city of Omaha the aggregate school tax can not in any one year exceed thirteen mills on the dollar upon the actual value. (See Sec. 79-2722). • NOTE — At the time property was assessed at one-fifth its full actual value, prior to 1921, the maximum levy for cities of this class was 15 mills. When the law was amended to provide for taxation at the full value, a general Statute was passed reducing all levies to one - fifth, which made. the maximum city levy three mills. In 1925, the old Statute was amended, increasing the maximum levy from 15 to 18 mills, the general Statute providing for the reduc - tion to three mills being disregarded, doubtless through an oversight. The amended Statute apparently should have provided for a maximum levy of 3.6 mills.

STATE OF NEBRASKA STATEMENT NO. 17 How Tour Tax Dollar Is Divided The following statement shows the amount of taxes levied in the state for the year 1931 as shown by the tax lists of' the various coun - ties. It also shows how the average tax dollar is divided among the different governmental subdivisions of the state: 1981 1931 Per Cent State Tax : 1 $6,393,935.93 .12 County Tax ■. 10,311,386.07 .19 School Tax 26,902,029.70 .48 City and Village Tax (Including Terminal Taxes) 10,696,040.80 .19 Township Tax , 1,692,454.79 .02 Total $54,894,847.29 $1.00 (EXPLANATION: The above figures relating to the division of the tax dollar are the average for the State. The division of the tax dollar is governed by the amount of taxes levied • in different sub - divisions and therefore would be more or less in different taxing subdivisions.) STATE LOCAL 12% 88% From the above it will be noted that of every dollar paid in taxes by the average taxpayer, Twelve Cents will be spent by the State and Eighty-Eight Cents will be spent Locally.
